abstract: Rupert Murdoch is buying another paper because he is a sentimentalist, not because he has great skill at making money with them.
snippet: Rupert Murdoch is buying another paper because he is a sentimentalist, not because he has great skill at making money with them.
lead_paragraph: You can bet serious money — billions even — that the article about the sale of The Wall Street Journal and the rest of Dow Jones & Company in today’s Journal will be fully and ferociously reported, with no quarter given to its new owner, Rupert Murdoch.

headline.main: Murdoch’s Journal: Don’t Expect ‘Hedgeless Funds’ Headlines
headline.print_headline: Murdoch’s Journal: Don’t Expect ‘Hedgeless Funds’ Headlines

abstract: Rupert Murdoch has enough support from the Bancroft family for his News Corporation to buy the publisher of The Wall Street Journal.
snippet: Rupert Murdoch has enough support from the Bancroft family for his News Corporation to buy the publisher of The Wall Street Journal.
lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch finally won his long-coveted prize yesterday, gaining enough support from the deeply divided Bancroft family to buy Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal and one of the world’s most respected news sources, for $5 billion.

headline.main: Dow Jones Deal Gives Murdoch a Coveted Prize
headline.print_headline: DOW JONES DEAL GIVES MURDOCH A COVETED PRIZE

byline.original: By Richard Pérez-Peña and Andrew Ross Sorkin

abstract: Rupert Murdoch is likely to accept losses on The Wall Street Journal at first in order to win the long-term war.
snippet: Rupert Murdoch is likely to accept losses on The Wall Street Journal at first in order to win the long-term war.

headline.main: In Murdoch’s Past, Clues to The Journal’s Future
headline.print_headline: Now What Happens to The Journal?

abstract: The Dow reversed course from a slump yesterday that led to a sell-off in Asia and carried over into Europe.
snippet: The Dow reversed course from a slump yesterday that led to a sell-off in Asia and carried over into Europe.
lead_paragraph: Stocks closed higher on Wall Street today after a rally late in the session, reversing course from a slump yesterday that led to a sell-off in Asia and carried over in Europe because of concerns about the mortgage industry.

headline.main: Stocks Close Higher After Late Rally

byline.original: By Jeremy W. Peters and Wayne Arnold

abstract: Dow Jones & Company, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, said today it had signed a merger agreement with Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation.
snippet: Dow Jones & Company, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, said today it had signed a merger agreement with Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation.
lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch finally won his long-coveted prize yesterday, gaining enough support from the deeply divided Bancroft family to buy Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal and one of the world’s most respected news sources, for $5 billion.

headline.main: Dow Jones Deal Gives Murdoch a Coveted Prize

byline.original: By Richard Pérez-Peña and Andrew Ross Sorkin

abstract: In the advertising community, executives expressed optimism that Mr. Murdoch would invest resources in The Journal, making it more attractive to advertisers.
snippet: In the advertising community, executives expressed optimism that Mr. Murdoch would invest resources in The Journal, making it more attractive to advertisers.
lead_paragraph: Villain, savior or just an ambitious businessman? In Manhattan’s financial district yesterday, core Wall Street Journal readers who had been following the drawn-out Dow Jones takeover events had no shortage of opinions about Rupert Murdoch.

headline.main: Readers May Be Wary, but Ad Executives Are Not
headline.print_headline: Readers of The Journal May Be Wary of Murdoch, but Advertising Executives Are Elated

byline.original: By Louise Story and Angel Jennings

abstract: Since the News Corporation‘s offer for Dow Jones & Company was made public three months ago, Rupert Murdoch’s business career, character and motives have been dissected in an effort to predict what he might do as the owner of The Wall Street Journal.
lead_paragraph: Since the News Corporation‘s offer for Dow Jones & Company was made public three months ago, Rupert Murdoch’s business career, character and motives have been dissected in an effort to predict what he might do as the owner of The Wall Street Journal.

headline.main: Guessing Murdoch’s Strategy for The Journal

abstract: Dow Chemical, the largest chemicals group in the United States, is considering making a rival offer for Imperial Chemical Industries, the British maker of Dulux paints, The Telegraph reported.
lead_paragraph: Dow Chemical, the largest chemicals group in the United States, is considering making a rival offer for Imperial Chemical Industries, the British maker of Dulux paints, The Telegraph reported.

headline.main: Dow Chemical Said to Prepare Imperial Bid

abstract: Villain, savior or just an ambitious businessman? In Manhattan’s financial district Tuesday, core Wall Street Journal readers who had been following the drawn-out Dow Jones takeover events had no shortage of opinions about Rupert Murdoch.

headline.main: The Dow Jones Sale: Wall Street Speaks

abstract: While Rupert Murdoch finally won his long-coveted prize — gaining enough support from the deeply divided Bancroft family to buy Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal — closing the $5 billion deal was a marathon of conference calls and all-nighters for those involved in the deal-making process.
lead_paragraph: While Rupert Murdoch finally won his long-coveted prize — gaining enough support from the deeply divided Bancroft family to buy Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal — closing the $5 billion deal was a marathon of conference calls and all-nighters for those involved in the deal-making process.

headline.main: Murdoch and Dow Jones: How The Deal Got Done

abstract: On Tuesday night’s episode of “The Charlie Rose Show,” DealBook’s Andrew Ross Sorkin sat down with Charlie Rose and The New Yorker’s Ken Auletta to talk about the News Corporation‘s $5 billion deal for Dow Jones. You can watch the full video after the jump.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night’s episode of “The Charlie Rose Show,” DealBook’s Andrew Ross Sorkin sat down with Charlie Rose and The New Yorker’s Ken Auletta to talk about the News Corporation‘s $5 billion deal for Dow Jones. You can watch the full video after the jump.

abstract: Don’t count on Rupert Murdoch holding on to Dow Jones and the Wall Street Journal for the long term, warns Slate’s Jack Shafer, the media critic who has written many scathing columns about Mr. Murdoch since the media baron’s News Corporation made its bid in May. He’ll keep it long enough to destroy it, then sell it off, Mr. Shafer predicts.
lead_paragraph: Don’t count on Rupert Murdoch holding on to Dow Jones and the Wall Street Journal for the long term, warns Slate’s Jack Shafer, the media critic who has written many scathing columns about Mr. Murdoch since the media baron’s News Corporation made its bid in May. He’ll keep it long enough to destroy it, then sell it off, Mr. Shafer predicts.

headline.main: Murdoch’s Deal History Shows Fickle Streak
